awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Aggregation Mechanisms in Carbon Nanomaterials Based on Pi-conjugated Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Hans Lischka of Texas Tech University at Lubbock and Professor Miklos Kertesz of Georgetown University are studying the mechanisms of aggregation of individual polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon molecules into assemblies.  Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons are ubiquitous molecules that occur in practically all carbonaceous materials, including ones as familiar to the general public as soot.  Facilitation as well as inhibition of aggregation requires understanding of the driving forces for this process at the molecular level.  Such molecular level of understanding is central to the control of the formation of functional carbon nanomaterials and crucial for the rational development of organic semiconductors for application in electronic and optical technologies, such as organic solar cells, electronic sensors and quantum computing systems.  During the course of conducting this collaborative project, graduate and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds will be trained, and summer courses on the science of soft matter that are geared towards high school students will be conducted.  The software protocols developed will be publicly shared with the scientific community and tutorials on quantum mechanical methods geared to the general public will be developed. 
 
The project addresses an urgently needed systematic study of the radical and biradical character of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon molecules and its role in their aggregation into nano-sized structures.  Molecular level understanding of cluster formation is crucial for the rational development of organic nanocarbons for application in electronic and optical technologies.   Computational modeling with highest-level quantum chemical methods (multireference theory) in combination with lower level, but computationally more efficient methods (ab initio single reference methods and density functional theory) will be employed.  Descriptors will be used to construct and calculate promising dimer and trimer stacking combinations to evaluate the pancake interaction strength and compare them with experimental observations. These quantum chemical simulations will be extended by global modeling activities which will reflect in more detail the condensed phase structure based on the available interaction data of the quantum chemical calculations. This project includes collaboration with two experimental groups, providing structural and other characterization data. This project is expected to lead to a new and systematic approach to data collection based on computational work in the form of structural and energetic information with additional descriptors for biradical character. In the longer term, a better understanding of pancake bonding in the context of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons has the potential to provide important new insights into the mechanisms of radical and biradical aggregation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Aggregates of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) form a major fraction of carbon nanostructures. They provide not only the basis for the development of new organic semiconductors to be used as optical devices and sensors, in spintronics, in battery technology, as components in molecular machines, and for singlet fission, but are also of interest for the efficient utilization of traditional, petroleum-based carbon resources. A dominating theme of the PAH structures is p-stacking. This interaction occurs in different variations. In its simplest form it is characterized by standard intermolecular forces (van der Waals interactions). However, in case of PAHs possessing radical or biradical character, an interesting additional interaction based on chemical bonding is found denoted pancake bonding. Figure 1 shows a typical case where the pancake bonding for a dimer of the paradigmatic radical phenalenyl is shown. The overlapping orbitals lead to chemical pancake bonding. This type of bonding leads to significantly stronger interactions and is supposed to exert significant influence on carbon nanomaterials.

The goal of this project was to study computationally the properties of PAHs with respect to their open shell character and the evaluation of pancake bonding. Such calculations are highly demanding and require special theoretical methods in the form of multireference (MR) procedures. For that purpose, the COLUMBUS program system was used, for which the PI is one of the originators and major developers. The aim of the MR calculations was to provide benchmark results for selected open shell descriptors like unpaired electron densities and singlet/triplet splittings. The results obtained by the MR calculations are reliable but computationally expensive. They were taken as reference for adjusting the fractional occupation number weighted electron density (FOD) data of the computationally less demanding density functional theory (DFT). The combination of these two approaches for the calculation of the open shell character leads to a good compromise which opens the possibilities for reliable and significantly faster predictions of larger compounds. Figure 2 shows the good correlation obtained between the MR data and for one chosen DFT variant with a test set of 29 PAH compounds.

In the quest for the construction of a variety of PAHs with controllable open shell character, phenalenyl oligomers were constructed by connecting them via acetylene bridges. The interesting and important point of these connections is that the strength of the interaction between different phenalenyl monomers depends on the topology of the connection. When phenalenyl carbon atoms which contribute to the singly occupied molecular orbital (SOMO) are connected by the acetylene bridge, the interaction is strong, the singlet/triplet splitting is large, and the open shell character is small. Conversely, connecting non-contributing carbon atoms leads to weak interactions and strong open shell character. Figure 3 shows the SOMO and the different connection options between phenalenyl molecules. Type I indicates a strong interaction, type II a weak one and type III an intermediate case. This network of different connections has been used to construct compounds up to phenalenyl tetramers resulting in a scale of open shell character which could be chosen for specific device or sensor applications.

In conclusion, our MR Columbus work has made available reliable characterization of open shell character. The combination with DFT calculations opens new opportunities for the computationally efficient characterization of larger-sized molecules or molecular complexes. Acetylene-connected phenalenyls appear as interesting, tunable open shell compounds which can be used for stacking arrangements to create magnetic structures. Moreover, this work can be applied to PAHs which are of great interest as single-molecule emitters for quantum science and technologies for which accurate spectroscopic MR calculations are urgently needed.

 


Last Modified: 09/18/2024
Modified by: Hans Lischka
